'''''My Story''''' (or '''''Mon histoire''''') is a tell-all memoir by Canadian Julie Couillard. It was first written in French, then during summer 2008, translated into English. Both versions were published across Canada in October 2008.
Couillard first appeared in the national media when she dated the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Canada)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]], [[Maxime Bernier]]. The [[Maxime Bernier#Couillard affair / Cabinet resignation|Bernier-Couillard Affair]] erupted in May 2008 over confidential, NATO-related documents left at Couillard's house. Media coverage, and Bernier's reaction, left Couillard feeling victimized. To help dispel rumours regarding her life and her role with Bernier, Couillard signed a book deal.
In her book, she recounts her early years, describes her relationship with Bernier, and reveals his confidential opinions.
Intended to be released on October 14, 2008, the book's release date was moved forward when that same day was selected for the [[Canadian federal election, 2008|Canadian federal election]]. Bernier dismissed the embarrassing allegations against him in her book as ridiculous. Though ''My Story'' was released eight days prior to the election, Bernier nonetheless was re-elected in his district of [[Beauce (electoral district)|Beauce]]. The English version peaked at #6 on ''[[La Presse (Canada)|La Presse]]'''s bestseller list while the French version reached #5. Critics found Couillard's story self-righteous and sometimes conveniently vague, but noted that it provided a unique view into the government's inner circle.
==Background== Julie Couillard began dating [[Conservative Party of Canada]] Member of Parliament, [[Maxime Bernier]], in April 2007. The media started covering her in August, when she wore a revealing dress to Bernier's swearing-in ceremony for his new position as [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Canada)|Minister of Foreign Affairs]].<ref>{{cite news|first=Nelson |last=Wyatt |title=Couillard doesn't hold back in new book: Publisher |work=[[Canadian Online Explorer]] |agency=[[The Canadian Press]] |date=September 9, 2008 |url=http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Canada/CanadaVotes/News/2008/09/09/6712366-cp.html |accessdate=October 4, 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20080912041646/http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Canada/CanadaVotes/News/2008/09/09/6712366-cp.html |archivedate=September 12, 2008 }}</ref> The couple had first met at a restaurant-dinner with business associates.<ref name=Blatchford>{{cite news |first = Christie |last = Blatchford |title = Couillard told to trash NATO briefings, book reveals |work = [[The Globe and Mail]] |publisher = CTVglobemedia Publishing |location = Toronto |date = October 2, 2008 |url = http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081002.wblatch02/BNStory/National/home?cid=al_gam_mostemail |accessdate = October 4, 2008 }}</ref> Couillard and Bernier dated until December 2007 but continued seeing each other until April 2008. Their relationship became the subject of a [[List of Canadian political scandals|political scandal]] which brought about intense media attention. As the scandal unfolded, Couillard decided to write an autobiography, telling her side of the story.<ref name=Johnson/><ref>{{cite news |url = http://www2.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=df984ff6-6f28-4c60-ba5d-9dc01f510cd8 |accessdate = January 31, 2009 |title = Julie Couillard inks book deal |work = Canada.com |publisher = Canwest Publishing |date = June 20, 2008 }}</ref> She formally signed a contract in July with publishers, [[McClelland & Stewart]]; and with the help of journalist, Serge Demers, a [[ghostwriter]], she wrote ''My Story'' in French within a few months.<ref name=Johnson>{{cite news |first = William |last = Johnson |authorlink= William Johnson (author) |title = The perils of Julie |work = [[The Globe and Mail]] |publisher = CTVglobemedia Publishing |location = Toronto |date = October 11, 2008 |page = D4 |url = http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20081011.BKJULI11/TPStory/Entertainment/Books |accessdate = February 2, 2009 }}</ref> The publisher translated the text into English.
==Bernier-Couillard affair== Bernier was elected as a Conservative [[star candidate]] in Quebec and became the [[Minister of Industry (Canada)|Minister of Industry]] before being reassigned to the [[Minister of Foreign Affairs (Canada)|Ministry of Foreign Affairs]] in August 2007. Though his relationship with Couillard had ended in December, they continued with occasional trysts.<ref name=Geddes>{{cite journal |first = John |last = Geddes |author2=Gohier, Philippe |title = Maxime Bernier's Femme Fatale |journal = [[Maclean's]] |issue = |date = June 9, 2008 |page=20 |issn = 0024-9262 }}</ref> In April 2008, as Bernier hurriedly departed Couillard's home, he left behind confidential, [[NATO]]-related briefing notes; they were from the [[2008 Bucharest summit]]. He asked Couillard to destroy them. Couillard, on the other hand, put the notes aside and forgot about them until May when she returned the notes to a foreign affairs office. Significant discussion about the affair was then voiced in both the [[Canadian House of Commons]] and the Standing Committee on Public Safety and National Security.<ref>{{cite news |title = Couillard known to police before controversy hit media: RCMP |agency = [[CBC News]] |work = [[cbc.ca]] |publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date = June 10, 2008 |url = http://www.cbc.ca/canada/story/2008/06/10/bernier-hearing.html?ref=rss |accessdate = January 30, 2009 }}</ref>
After discussions with [[Prime Minister of Canada]], [[Stephen Harper]], Bernier resigned as Minister of Foreign Affairs, a day before the airing of Couillard's interview with [[TVA (TV network)|TVA]].<ref>{{cite news |first = Les |last = Whittington |title = Embattled Bernier resigns |agency = Ottawa Bureau |work = [[The Toronto Star]] |date = May 26, 2008 |url= http://www.thestar.com/News/Canada/article/431201 |accessdate = October 5, 2008 }}</ref> Political commentators called the affair a threat to national security due to Bernier's carelessness and to Couillard's background with motorcycle biker gangs.<ref>{{cite news |first = Allan |last = Woods |agency = Ottawa Bureau |title = Harper dismisses revelations about minister |work = [[The Toronto Star]] |date = May 9, 2008 |url = http://www.thestar.com/article/423209 |accessdate = October 5, 2008 }}</ref> According to Couillard, Bernier's response to the subsequent media coverage made her feel betrayed and abandoned.<ref>{{cite news |first = Louis Mathieu |last = Gagne |title = Bernier's ex dishes about scandal |work = [[Canadian Online Explorer]] |agency = [[Sun Media Corporation]] |date = May 26, 2008 |url= http://cnews.canoe.ca/CNEWS/Politics/2008/05/26/pf-5669276.html |accessdate = October 5, 2008 }}</ref>
==Content== The book begins as an [[autobiography]]. Couillard was born in the late-1960s in the Montreal district of [[Ville-Émard]]; then she moved to the suburb of [[Lorraine, Quebec|Lorraine]] when she was 4. Her parents often fought as her mother believed that her husband was unfaithful; the family incurred financial problems when Couillard's father changed careers. At age 12, Couillard was diagnosed with epilepsy. At age 17, she bought several properties with a boyfriend. They lived together briefly before breaking up and selling the properties. Couillard then became a friend, then lover, of Gilles Giguère, a money lender who was associated with the controversial, motorcycle club, [[Hells Angels]]. In 1996, after the police raided Giguère's apartment and (according to Couillard) threatened him, Giguère became sullen and withdrawn: the police had charged him with conspiracy to commit murder. But two months later, they let the charge drop. Giguère was soon murdered.<ref name=Gillis>{{cite web |url = http://blog.macleans.ca/2008/10/02/a-liveblog-review-of-my-story-by-julie-couillard/ |title = A liveblog review of My Story, by Julie Couillard |accessdate = October 4, 2008 |last = Gillis |first = Charlie |date = October 2, 2008 |work = [[Maclean's|macleans.ca]] |publisher = Maclean's }}</ref><ref name=Ivison>{{cite news |first = John |last = Ivison |title = Bernier asked Couillard to trash NATO documents: book |work = [[National Post]] |date = October 1, 2008 |url= http://www.nationalpost.com/most_popular/story.html?id=853268 |accessdate = October 4, 2008 }} {{Dead link|date=April 2012|bot=H3llBot}}</ref>
In 1997, Couillard met Stéphane Sirois, a reputed ''enforcer'' and drug dealer, member of the [[Outlaw motorcycle club|Rockers]] a Hells Angels affiliate club. They married. However, financial problems interfered with their relationship; furthermore, Couillard had cheated on Sirois with a man named Bruno. During their divorce, Sirois became an informant for the police and entered a [[witness protection]] program. Couillard then became pregnant with Bruno's child, and had an abortion; they subsequently separated. Following further personal, financial problems, Couillard declared bankruptcy in 2002. She then began an affair with a married man who abandoned her while they visited [[Venice, Italy]]. When she returned to Canada, Couillard launched a security firm, Integrated Global Solutions, along with an auto-leasing business. Meanwhile, she began to date Bernard Coté, an aide to federal [[Minister of Public Works and Government Services (Canada)|Minister of Public Works]], [[Michael Fortier]]. Couillard then introduced Coté to Philippe Morin of the Kevlar Group, a real estate company which signed a deal with the federal government to acquire land from Kevlar. When the deal became public Coté's involvement was considered a conflict of interest and Fortier, responsible for the actions of his staff, was forced to resign, despite Morin denying any connection between Kevlar and Couillard.<ref name=Gillis/><ref name=Ivison/>
Then, in April 2007, while attending a [[Conservative Party of Canada]] fundraising affair, Couillard was asked to consider being a candidate for the party. Later, she attended a dinner where she met [[Maxime Bernier]]; they began dating. Bernier registered Couillard as his designated traveling companion with the Ministry of Foreign Affairs in order for Couillard to accompany Bernier on government business.
In her book, Couillard characterizes Bernier as intellectually lazy, preoccupied with his appearance, and as concerned that he appears gay. She writes further that Bernier privately criticized Prime Minister [[Stephen Harper]]'s eating habits and his physique. She adds that Bernier spoke with party supporters about replacing Harper as the party leader, and says that Bernier opposed the invasion of Iraq contrary to his party's stance. Further revelations regarding Bernier include that he whispered negative comments to Couillard about members of his [[Electoral district (Canada)|electoral district]]; and that he did not own a laptop, yet frequently used her house and home computer as a second office.
Couillard goes on to describe the NATO document incident and the ensuing media coverage from her perspective.<ref name=Gillis/><ref name=Whyte>{{cite journal |first = Kenneth |last = Whyte |title = Julie Couillard talks with Kenneth Whyte |journal = [[Maclean's]] |date = October 20, 2008 |issue = 41 |volume = 121 |pages =14–17 |issn = 0024-9262 }}</ref>
==Publication and reception== The original publication date for the book was October 14, 2008. After the [[Canadian federal election, 2008|Canadian federal election]] was called and set for that day the book's release was re-scheduled to October 6, eight days before the election in which Bernier was seeking re-election.<ref>{{cite news |title = Tell-all book by MP's ex-girlfriend to hit stores before election |agency = [[CBC News]] |work = [[cbc.ca]] |publisher = [[Canadian Broadcasting Corporation]] |date = September 9, 2008 |url = http://www.cbc.ca/arts/story/2008/09/09/mtl-couillardautobiography0909.html |accessdate = October 7, 2008 }} {{Dead link|date=April 2011|bot=RjwilmsiBot}}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first = Daniel |last = LeBlanc |title = Bernier dismisses Couillard allegations as 'marketing strategy' |work = [[The Globe and Mail]] |publisher = CTVglobemedia Publishing |location = Toronto |date = October 2, 2008 |url = http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081002.wcouillard02/BNStory/National |accessdate = October 4, 2008 }}</ref> The English version was published as a hard cover by [[McClelland & Stewart]] while the French version was released by Montreal publishers, Les Editions de l'Homme, as a trade paperback.<ref>{{cite news |first = Kevin |last = Dougherty |title = Couillard's tell-all book to hit the store shelves Oct. 6 |work = [[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]] |page = A14 |date = September 10, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first = Andy |last = Johnson |title = 'My Story' about vindication, not revenge: Couillard |work = [[CTV News]] |publisher = CTVglobemedia Publishing |date = October 7, 2008 |url = http://www.ctv.ca/servlet/ArticleNews/story/CTVNews/20081007/my_story_couillard_081007/20081007/ |accessdate = January 11, 2009 }}</ref> According to ''[[La Presse (Canada)|La Presse]]'', 17,000 copies were printed; 5,000 sold in the first two weeks.<ref>{{cite news |first = Karim |last = Benessaieh |title = Biographie de Julie Couillard: les ventes ne lèvent pas |work = [[La Presse (Canada)|La Presse]] |date = October 23, 2008 |language = French |url = http://www.cyberpresse.ca/dossiers/julie-couillard/200810/23/01-32045-biographie-de-julie-couillard-les-ventes-ne-levent-pas.php |accessdate = November 2, 2008 }}</ref> In the Montreal market, the book was listed on the bestseller list at #6 for two weeks while the French version spent one week at #5.<ref>{{cite news |title = Best Sellers |work = [[The Gazette (Montreal)|The Gazette]] |location = [[Montreal]] |date = October 11–18, 2008 }}</ref>
In response to the book, Bernier dismissed the contents as "soap-opera politics and completely ridiculous" and denied ever criticizing Harper or constituents.<ref>{{cite news |first = Tobi |last = Cohen |title = Bernier dismisses Couillard's tell-all book |agency = [[The Canadian Press]] |work = [[The Toronto Star]] |location = Toronto |page = A21 |date = October 2, 2008 |url = http://www.thestar.com/federalelection/article/510088 |accessdate = October 4, 2008 }}</ref> ''[[The Ottawa Citizen]]'' reviewer, Chris Cobb, and ''[[The Globe and Mail]]'''s, Christie Blatchford called Couillard's story self-righteous, contradictory, and conveniently vague.<ref name=Blatchford/><ref name=Cobb>{{cite news |first = Chris |last = Cobb |title = A stake through the heart |agency = [[The Ottawa Citizen]] |work = Canada.com |publisher = Canwest Publishing |page = B1 |date = October 4, 2008 |url = http://www.canada.com/ottawacitizen/news/story.html?id=67a21ad2-7390-4d53-9102-bd918250919d |accessdate = October 4, 2008 }}</ref> Cobb commented that "viewed through a political lens, it's an entertaining page-turner" as it provides "a rare glimpse inside the closed, controlled society that is the Harper government."<ref name=Cobb/> Additionally, writer, [[William Johnson (author)|William Johnson]], said the book story unfolds like pulp fiction or a soap opera and compares Couillard to the abused heroine in ''[[Justine (Sade)|Justine]]'' who does not learn from her calamities.<ref name=Johnson/>
Bernier went on to win his election in [[Beauce (electoral district)|Beauce]] with 62% of the vote. Harper won re-election as prime-minister; he did not appoint Bernier to a cabinet position.<ref>{{cite news |agency = [[The Canadian Press]] |title = Maxime Bernier not bitter about being excluded from cabinet |work = [[Toronto Star]] |date= October 30, 2008 |url = http://www.thestar.com/News/Canada/article/527746 |accessdate = November 21, 2008 }}</ref> Stemming from Couillard's actions during the entire affair, the [[Royal Canadian Mounted Police]] (RCMP) launched investigations on how she obtained the secret documents; on whether Couillard's mother was offered a [[patronage]] appointment by a Conservative Party official to the [[Immigration and Refugee Board of Canada]]; and on whether there was [[influence peddling]] during the land sale between the Kevlar Group and [[Public Works and Government Services Canada|Public Works]].<ref name=LeBlanc>{{cite news |first = Daniel |last = LeBlanc |title = Couillard says firm hired her for Tory contacts |work = [[The Globe and Mail]] |publisher = CTVglobemedia Publishing |location = Toronto |format = fee required |date = October 3, 2008 |url = http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/RTGAM.20081003.wcouillard03/BNStory/National/home |accessdate = October 4, 2008 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |first = Lawrence |last = Martin |title = So much for Mad Max Bernier and Bikergate |work = [[The Globe and Mail]] |publisher = CTVglobemedia Publishing |location = Toronto |format = fee required |date = October 2, 2008 |url = http://www.theglobeandmail.com/servlet/story/LAC.20081002.COMARTIN02/TPStory/National |accessdate = October 4, 2008 }}</ref>
